list.title: Question 1
list.content:
Let $f(x) = x^4+5x^3+ax^2+bx+2$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$, where $a,b$ are
constants. The remainder when $f(x)$ is divided by $(x-1)$ is $6$, and
the remainder when $f(x)$ is divided by $(x+2)$ is $-6$. Find the value
of $a$ and the value of $b$.
list.markScheme:
Using the remainder theorem, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(1) &= 6 \\[6pt]
1^4+5(1)^3+a(1)^2+b(1)+2 &= 6 \\[7pt]
1 + 5 + a + b + 2 &= 6 \\[7pt]
a + b &= -2 \hspace{3.9em} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(-2) &= -6 \\[6pt]
(-2)^4+5(-2)^3+a(-2)^2+b(-2)+2 &= -6 \\[7pt]
16 - 40 + 4a - 2b + 2 &= -6 \\[7pt]
4a -2b &= 16 \hspace{8em} \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, solving the
system of linear equations (1)-(2) for $a$ and $b$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{0.8em} \answer{a = 2}\hspace{0.525em} \text{ and } \hspace{0.525em}\answer{b=-4}\end{aligned}
$$

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
When the resulting product of $3x^2+7x-6$ multiplied by $ax+1$ is divided by $x-1$ the remainder is $-4$.
Find the integer $a$.

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
Given that $(x-4)$ is a factor of $f(x) = x^3 - 2x^2 + ax + b$ and that
division of $f(x)$ by $(x+2)$ leaves a remainder of $18$, find the value
of $a$ and the value of $b$.
list.markScheme:
Using the factor theorem, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(4) &= 0 \\[5pt]
4^3 - 2(4)^2 + a(4) + b &= 0 \\[6pt]
32 + 4a + b &= 0 \\[6pt]
4a + b &= -32 \hspace{2em} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

Using the remainder
theorem, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(-2) &= 18 \\[5pt]
(-2)^3 - 2(-2)^2 + a(-2) + b &= 18 \\[6pt]
-16 - 2a + b &= 18 \\[6pt]
-2a + b &= 34  \hspace{6em} \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, solving the
system of two linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $a$ and $b$, we find

$$
\begin{aligned}
\answer{a = -11}\hspace{0.525em}\text{ and }\hspace{0.525em}\answer{b = 12}\end{aligned}
$$

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
The quadratic equation $x^2 - kx + (k-1) = 0$ has roots $\alpha$ and
$\beta$. Without solving the equation, find the possible values of the
real number $k$ given that $\alpha^2 + \beta^2 = 17$.
list.markScheme:
Using Vieta's formulas, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\alpha+\beta &=-\dfrac{a_1}{a_2} \\[4pt]
&= -\dfrac{(-k)}{1} \\[12pt]
&= k\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2.9em} \alpha\beta &= (-1)^2\bigg[\dfrac{a_0}{a_2}\bigg] \\[4pt]
&= \dfrac{k-1}{1} \\[12pt]
&= k-1\end{aligned}
$$

Hence we get

$$
\begin{aligned}(\alpha + \beta)^2  &= k^2 \\[6pt]\alpha^2 + \beta^2 + 2\alpha\beta &= k^2 \\[6pt]17 + 2(k - 1)  &=  k^2  \; [\text{since } \alpha^2 + \beta^2 = 17] \\[6pt]2k + 15  &=  k^2 \\[6pt]0 &= k^2 - 2k - 15 \\[7pt]0 &= (k+3)(k-5)\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{1.4em} \answer{k = -3,\hspace{0.25em}5}
$$

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
The quadratic equation $x^2 - kx + (k - 3) = 0$ has roots $\alpha$ and
$\beta$ such that $\alpha^2 + \beta^2 = 6$. Without solving the
equation, find the possible values of the real number $k$.
list.markScheme:
Using Vieta's formulas, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\alpha+\beta &=-\dfrac{a_1}{a_2} \\[4pt]
&= -\dfrac{(-k)}{1} \\[12pt]
&= k\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2.9em} \alpha\beta &= (-1)^2\bigg[\dfrac{a_0}{a_2}\bigg] \\[4pt]
&= \dfrac{k-3}{1} \\[12pt]
&= k-3 \end{aligned}
$$

Hence we get

$$
\begin{aligned}(\alpha + \beta)^2  &= k^2 \\[6pt]\alpha^2 + \beta^2 + 2\alpha\beta &= k^2 \\[6pt]6 + 2(k - 3)  &=  k^2 \; [\text{since } \alpha^2 + \beta^2 = 6] \\[6pt]\cancel{6} + 2k - \cancel{6}  &=  k^2 \\[6pt]0 &= k^2 - 2k \\[7pt]0 &= k(k - 2)\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{0.5em} \answer{k = 0,\hspace{0.25em}2}
$$

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
The polynomial $p(x) = 2x^4 + a_3x^3 + a_2x^2 + a_1x  - 12$ is divisible
by each of $(x + 1)$, $(x - 1)$ and $(x - 2)$.
Find the values of $a_1$, $a_2$ and $a_3$.
list.markScheme:
Using the factor theorem, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
p(-1) = p(1) = p(2) &= 0\end{aligned}
$$

Hence $-1$, $1$ and $2$ are
roots of $p(x)$. Let $x_4$ be the fourth root of $p(x)$.
Using Vieta's formula, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
(-1)(1)(2)x_4 &= (-1)^4\left[\dfrac{a_0}{a_4}\right] \\[5pt]
-2x_4 &= \dfrac{(-12)}{2} \\[13pt]
-2x_4 &= -6 \\[17pt]
x_4 &= 3\end{aligned}
$$

Hence we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
p(x) &= 2(x+1)(x-1)(x-2)(x-3) \\[6pt]
&= 2(x^2 - 1)(x^2 - 5x + 6) \\[6pt]
&= 2x^4 - 10x^3 + 10x^2  + 10x - 12\end{aligned}
$$

Hence we find
$\answer{a_1 = a_2 = 10}$
and  $\answer{a_3 = -10}$

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
When $p(x) = x^2 - 2x + p$ is divided by $x - r$, the remainder is $4$.
Given that $p,r \in \mathbb{R}$, find the largest possible value for
$p$.
list.markScheme:
Using the remainder theorem, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
p(r) &= 4 \\[6pt]
r^2 - 2r + p &= 4 \hspace{6em}\end{aligned}
$$

If we rewrite the equation
$(1)$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{6.4em} p &= -r^2 + 2r + 4 \\[6pt]
p &= -\big[r^2 - 2r\big] + 4 \\[6pt]
p &= -\big[(r-1)^2 - 1\big] + 4 \\[6pt]
p &= -(r-1)^2 + 5\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the largest possible value for
$p$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{10.8em} p_{\mathrm{max}} &= -(1-1)^2 + 5 \hspace{3em} [\text{when $r = 1$}] \\[6pt]
&= 0 + 5 \\[6pt]
&\answer{= 5}\end{aligned}
$$

list.title: Question 8
list.content: Consider the real polynomial $f(x)=x^5-5.5x^4-...-604.662$. The roots of the polynomial form a geometric sequence with first term $u_1$ and common ratio $r$. Where $u_1>0$ and $r<-1$. - Find two distinct functions for $u_1$ in terms of $r$. [3] - Hence find $u_1$ and $r$.[2]

list.title: Question 9
list.content: Consider the equation $32x^3 - 144x^2 + 214x - 105 = 0$. - Find the sum and product of the roots of this equation. [1] - The roots of this equation are three consecutive terms of an arithmetic sequence. Taking the roots to be $a - d, a, a + d$, solve the equation. [6]
list.markScheme:
- Using Vieta's formulas, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{sum of roots} &= -\dfrac{a_2}{a_3} \\[6pt]
  &= -\dfrac{(-144)}{32} \\[9pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{9}{2}}\end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{product of roots} &= (-1)^3\bigg[\dfrac{a_0}{a_3}\bigg] \hspace{0.9em} \\[6pt]
  &= -\dfrac{(-105)}{32} \\[9pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{105}{32}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (a-d)+a+(a+d) &= \dfrac{9}{2} \hspace{9.3em} \\[6pt]
  3a &= \dfrac{9}{2} \\[6pt]
  a &= \dfrac{3}{2}\end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  a(a-d)(a+d) &= \dfrac{105}{32} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{3}{2}\bigg[\dfrac{9}{4}-d^2\bigg] &= \dfrac{105}{32} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{9}{4}-d^2 &= \dfrac{35}{16} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{9}{4}-\dfrac{35}{16} &= d^2\\[6pt]
  d^2 &= \dfrac{1}{16} \\[6pt]
  d &= \dfrac{1}{4} \hspace{3em} \bigg[\text{or $-\dfrac{1}{4}$}\bigg]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the roots of the equation $32x^3 - 144x^2 + 214x - 105 = 0$
are

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.1em} a - d &= \dfrac{3}{2} - \dfrac{1}{4} = \hspace{0.525em}\answer{\dfrac{5}{4}} \\[8pt]
  a &=\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\dfrac{3}{2}} \\[8pt]
  a + d &= \dfrac{3}{2} + \dfrac{1}{4} = \hspace{0.525em}\answer{\dfrac{7}{4}}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 10
list.content: Consider the polynomial $p(z) = z^5 + z^4 - z^3 + z^2 + 4z + 2$, for $z \in \mathbb{C}$. - Write down the sum and product of the roots of $p(z) = 0$. [2] - Show that $(z+1)$ is a factor of $p(z)$. [2] The polynomial can be written in the form $p(z) = (z+1)^3(z^2 + cz + d)$. - Find the value of $c$ and the value of $d$. [5] - Hence find the complex roots of $p(z) = 0$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- Using Vieta's formulas, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{sum of roots} &= -\dfrac{a_4}{a_5} \hspace{1.1em} \\[6pt]
  &= -\dfrac{1}{1} \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= -1}\end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{product of roots} &= (-1)^5\bigg[\dfrac{a_0}{a_5}\bigg] \\[6pt]
  &= -\dfrac{2}{1} \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= -2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Evaluating $p(z)$ for $z = -1$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} p(-1) &= (-1)^5 + (-1)^4 - (-1)^3 + (-1)^2 + 4(-1) + 2 \\[6pt]
  &= 0\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, by factor theorem, $(z+1)$ is a factor of
$p(z)$.
- Evaluating $p(z)$ for $z = 0$ and $z = 1$, we have $p(0) = 2$ and
$p(1) = 8$.
  Hence, substituting $z = 0,\hspace{0.1em}1$ in the equation
$p(z) = (z+1)^3(z^2 + cz + d)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} p(0) &= (0+1)^3(0^2 + c(0) + d) \\[6pt]
  2 &= d \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{d = 2} \hspace{6.1em}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} p(1) &= (1+1)^3(1^2 + c(1) + 2) \\[6pt]
  8 &= 8(c+3) \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{c = -2} \hspace{5.2em}
  $$

- The complex roots of $p(z) = 0$ are the complex roots of
$z^2 - 2z + 2 = 0$.
  Hence, using the quadratic formula, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4em} z &= \dfrac{-(-2)\pm\sqrt{2^2-4(1)(2)}}{2(1)} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{2 \pm 2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}{2} \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= 1 \pm {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 11
list.content: Two distinct roots for the polynomial equation $z^4 - 10z^3 + cz^2 + dz + 170$ are $a + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ and $1 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}b$ where $a,b,c,d \in \mathbb{Z}$, $b > 0$. - Write down the other two roots in terms of $a$ and $b$. [1] - Find the value of $a$ and the value of $b$. [6]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{a - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu},\hspace{0.25em}1 - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}b}$
- Using Vieta's formulas, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{sum of roots} &= -\dfrac{a_3}{a_4} \\[6pt]
  (a + \cancel{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}) + (a - \cancel{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}) + (1 + \bcancel{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}b}) + (1 - \bcancel{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}b}) &= -\dfrac{(-10)}{1} \hspace{7.5em} \\[12pt]
  2a + 2 &= 10 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{5em} \answer{a = 4}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{product of roots} &= (-1)^4\bigg[\dfrac{a_0}{a_4}\bigg] \\[6pt]
  (4 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})(4 - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})(1 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}b)(1 - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}b) &= (-1)^4\bigg[\dfrac{170}{1}\bigg] \hspace{2em} \\[12pt]
  17(1 + b^2) &= 170 \\[16pt]
  1 + b^2 &= 10 \\[16pt]
  b^2 &= 9 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{13.4em} \answer{b = 3}  \hspace{3em} [\text{since $b > 0$}]
  $$

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
When $p(x) = x^2 - 2x - c$ is divided by $(x-r)$, the remainder is
$-5$.
Given that $c, r \in \mathbb{R}$, find the smallest possible value for
$c$.
list.markScheme:
Using the remainder theorem, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
p(r) &= -5 \\[6pt]
r^2 - 2r - c &= -5 \hspace{6em} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

If we rewrite
the equation $(1)$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{4.8em} c &= r^2 - 2r + 5 \\[6pt]
&= \big[(r - 1)^2 - 1\big] + 5 \\[6pt]
&= (r - 1)^2 + 4\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the smallest possible value for
$c$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{9.4em} c_{\mathrm{min}} &= (1-1)^2 + 4 \hspace{3em} [\text{when $r = 1$}] \\[6pt]
&= 0 + 4 \\[6pt]
&\answer{= 4}\end{aligned}
$$

list.title: Question 13
list.content: Let $f(x) = ax^3 + bx^2 + cx + d$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$, where $a,b,c,d \in \mathbb{Q}$. The diagram below shows part of the graph of $y = f(x)$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d78a10f2-621e-426c-91f2-9dea87dbacc5/images/89842500-91d4-4b78-a494-6ce2510b4acf/f2e9d58912ae2f10d7fdf9d12ee3b7594c2c45fb.svg) - Using the information shown in the diagram, find the values of $a$, $b$, $c$ and $d$.[4] - Let $g(x) = -\dfrac{3}{4}f(-2x+1)$. - Find the coordinates of the points where the graph of $y = g(x)$ intercepts the $x$-axis. - Find the $y$-intercept of the graph of $y = g(x)$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- From the diagram, we see that the roots of the polynomial equation
$f(x) = 0$ are $-3$, $-1$ and $3$.
  Hence, using the factor theorem, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(x) &= a(x-3)(x+1)(x+3) \\[6pt]
  &= a(x^2-9)(x+1) \\[6pt]
  &= a(x^3 + x^2 - 9x - 9) \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we substitute
$x = 0$ in the expression $(1)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.6em} f(0) &= a(0^3 + 0^2 - 9(0) - 9) \\[12pt]
  -3 &= -9a \hspace{3em} [\text{since $f(0) = -3$}] \\[6pt]
  a &= \dfrac{1}{3}\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we substitute $a = 1/3$ in the
expression $(1)$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(x) &= \dfrac{1}{3}(x^3 + x^2 - 9x - 9) \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{1}{3}x^3 + \dfrac{1}{3}x^2 - 3x - 3 \hspace{1.1em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{a = b = \dfrac{1}{3}}$
and  $\answer{c = d = -3}$
- 
  - Solving the equation $g(x) = 0$ for $x$, we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    -\dfrac{3}{4}f(-2x + 1) &= 0 \\[6pt]
    f(-2x + 1) &= 0 \\[12pt]
    -2x + 1 &= -3,\hspace{0.25em} -1,\hspace{0.25em} 3 \hspace{4em} \\[12pt]
    -2x &= -4,\hspace{0.25em} -2,\hspace{0.25em} 2 \\[12pt]
    x &= -1,\hspace{0.25em}1,\hspace{0.25em}2\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence
the coordinates of the $x$-intercepts of the graph of $y = g(x)$
are

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \answer{(-1,0),\hspace{0.25em}(1,0),\hspace{0.25em}(2,0)}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Evaluating $y=g(x)$ for $x = 0$, we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{10.9em} y &= g(0) \\[10pt]
    &= -\dfrac{3}{4}f(2(0)+1) \\[6pt]
    &= -\dfrac{3}{4}f(1) \\[6pt]
    &= -\dfrac{3}{4}\hspace{-0.2em}\left[\dfrac{1}{3}(1)^3 + \dfrac{1}{3}(1)^2 - 3(1) - 3\right] \\[4pt]
    &=-\dfrac{3}{4}\hspace{-0.2em}\left[-\dfrac{16}{3}\right] \\[10pt]
    &= 4\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the $y$-intercept of the graph of
$y = g(x)$ is
$\answer{\mathrm{P}(0,4)}$

list.title: Question 14
list.content:
Consider the equation $2z^4 + az^3 + bz^2 +cz + d = 0$, where
$a, b, c, d \in \mathbb{R}$ and $z \in \mathbb{C}$. Two of the roots of
the equation are $\log_2 10$ and
${\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sqrt{5}$ and the sum of all the
roots is $4 + \log_25$.
Show that $15a + d + 90 = 0$.
list.markScheme:
Since ${\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sqrt{5}$ is a root, its
conjugate $- {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sqrt{5}$ is also a
root of the equation.
If $z_4$ is the fourth root of the equation, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}\bcancel{{\mathrm{i}\mkern 1mu}\sqrt{5}} + (- \bcancel{{\mathrm{i}\mkern 1mu}\sqrt{5}}) + \log_{2} 10 + z_4 &= 4 + \log_{2} 5 \; [\text{sum of roots}] \\[6pt]z_4 &= 4 + \log_{2} 5 - \log_{2} 10 \\[6pt]z_4 &= 4 + \cancel{\log_{2} 5} - (\log_{2} 2 + \cancel{\log_{2} 5}) \\[6pt]z_4 &= 4 - 1 \; [\text{since } \log_{2} 2 = 1] \\[6pt]z_4 &= 3\end{aligned}
$$

Using Vieta's formulas, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
-\dfrac{a}{2} &= 4 + \log_25 \hspace{2.75em} [\text{sum of roots}] \\[6pt]
a &= -8 - 2\log_25\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{5.4em} (-1)^4\bigg[\dfrac{d}{2}\bigg] &= ({\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sqrt{5})(-{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sqrt{5})(\log_2 10)(3) \hspace{2.75em} [\text{product of roots}] \\[6pt]
d &= 30\log_210\end{aligned}
$$

Hence we get

$$
\begin{aligned}15a + d + 90 &= 15(-8 - 2\log_{2}5) + 30\log_{2}10 + 90 \\[6pt]&= -120 - \bcancel{30\log_{2}5}  +  30\log_{2}2 + \bcancel{30\log_{2}5} + 90 \\[6pt]&= -120 + 30 + 90  [\text{since } \log_{2} 2 = 1] \\[6pt]&\boxed{= 0}\end{aligned}
$$

list.title: Question 15
list.content: It is given that $f(x) = 2x^4 + 5x^3 + ax^2 + bx + 4$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$, where $a,b \in \mathbb{Z}$. - Given that $x^2 + x - 2$ is a factor of $f(x)$, find the values of $a$ and $b$. [4] - Factorise $f(x)$ into a product of linear factors. [4] - Sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$, labeling the maximum and minimum points and the $x$ and $y$ intercepts. [3] - Using your graph, state the range of values of $c$ for which $f(x) = c$ has exactly four real roots. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Factorising $x^2 + x - 2$ into a product of linear factors, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x^2 + x - 2 = (x-1)(x+2)\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence $(x-1)$ and $(x+2)$
are both factors of $f(x)$.
  Hence, using the factor theorem, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(1) &= 0 \\[6pt]
  2(1)^4 + 5(1)^3 + a(1)^2 + b(1) + 4 &= 0 \\[6pt]
  2 + 5 + a + b + 4 &= 0 \\[6pt]
  a + b &= -11 \hspace{3em} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using the factor theorem again, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(-2) &= 0 \hspace{4em} \\[6pt]
  2(-2)^4 + 5(-2)^3 + a(-2)^2 + b(-2) + 4 &= 0 \\[7pt]
  32 - 40 + 4a - 2b + 4 &= 0 \\[7pt]
  4a - 2b &= 4 \\[7pt]
  2a - b &= 2 \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the system of
two linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $a$ and $b$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{a = -3}\hspace{0.525em}\text{ and }\hspace{0.525em}\answer{b = -8}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we divide $2x^4 + 5x^3 - 3x^2 - 8x + 4$ by $x^2 + x - 2$, we have
Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(x) &= 2x^4 + 5x^3 - 3x^2 - 8x + 4 \\[6pt]
  &= (x^2 + x - 2)(2x^2 + 3x - 2) \\[6pt]
  &= (x-1)(x+2)(2x-1)(x+2) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= (x-1)(2x-1)(x+2)^2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1bd4cd72-a9fa-45a6-960b-36cd2036ef37/images/aab0e32b-f24b-45b1-918c-1af7fb3e580b/fee6121260f114c0cc689969551419dd8b20d6fc.svg)


- From the diagram, we see that the equation $f(x) = c$ has exactly
four real
  roots when
$\answer{0 < c < 6.92}$

list.title: Question 16
list.content: Let $p(x) = \dfrac{1}{4}x^5 - 2x^4 - 5x^3 + 40x^2 + 16x - 128$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. - For the polynomial equation $p(x) = 0$, state: - the sum of the roots; - the product of the roots. [3] A new polynomial is defined by $q(x) = p(2x-2)$. - For the polynomial equation $q(x) = 0$, find: - the sum of the roots; - the product of the roots. [5]

list.title: Question 17
list.content: Consider the family of polynomials of the form $P(x)=ax^3+bx^2+cx+d$ where coefficients $a$, $b$, $c$ and $d$ belong to the set $\{2,6,8,24\}$. - Find the number of possible polynomials if - each coefficient value can be repeated; - each coefficient must be different.[4] Consider the case where $P(x)$ has $x+3$ as a factor, two purely imaginary roots, and all the coefficients are different. - - By considering the sum of the roots, find the two possible combinations for coefficients $a$ and $b$. - Show that there is only one way to assign the values $a$, $b$, $c$, and $d$ if $P(0)=24$.[7] Now, consider the polynomial with the coefficients found in part (b) (ii). - - Express $P(x)$ as a product of one linear and one quadratic factor. - Determine the three roots of $P(x)$.[7]
list.markScheme:
- Let $X$ be the total number of polynomials.
  
  - Given that each coefficient value can be repeated, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    X&=4 \times 4 \times 4 \times 4\\[6pt]
    &=4^4\\[6pt]
    &=256.
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Therefore, there are $\tcbhighmath{256}$ possible polynomials if the coefficients can be repeated.
  - Given that each coefficient must be different, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    X&=4!\\[6pt]
    &=4 \times 3 \times 2 \times 1\\[6pt]
    &=24.
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Therefore, there are $\tcbhighmath{24}$ possible polynomials if each coefficient must be different.

- 
  - Let the roots be $x_1, x_2$ and $x_3$. Given that $x+3$ is a factor, $x_1=-3$ is a root. Complex roots occur in conjugate pairs, therefore if the other two roots are imaginary, we have $x_2 = \alpha \mathrm{i}$ and $x_3 = -\alpha \mathrm{i}$, where $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$. Hence, the sum of the roots is given by

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    x_1 + x_2 + x_3 &= -3 + \alpha \mathrm{i} - \alpha \mathrm{i} \\[6pt]
    &= -3
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Using the formula for the sum of the roots, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    x_1 + x_2 + x_3 &= -\dfrac{b}{a} \\[6pt]
    -3 &= -\dfrac{b}{a} \\[6pt]
    3a &= b
    \end{align*}
    $$

    We have that $a$ and $b$ belong to the set $\{2,6,8,24\}$ and $3a=b$. Therefore,
    $\tcbhighmath{\text{The two possible combinations are $a=2,\,b=6$ and $a=8,\,b=24$.}}$
  - If $P(0)=24$, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    P(0) &= a(0)^3 + b(0)^2 + c(0) + d \\[6pt]
    24 &= d
    \end{align*}
    $$

    The coefficients must all be different. If $d=24$, $b \neq 24$, so we have from part (b)(i) that $a=2$ and $b=6$. Therefore $c=8$.
    $\tcbhighmath{\text{If $P(0)=24$, we must have $a=2,\,b=6,\,c=8$ and $d=24$.}}$

- 
  - Our polynomial is $P(x) = 2x^3 + 6x^2 + 8x + 24$. Given that $x+3$ is a factor, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    2x^3 + 6x^2 + 8x + 24 &= (x+3)(2x^2 + ex + 8) \\[6pt]
    &= 2x^3 +ex^2 + 8x + 6x^2 +3ex + 24 \\[6pt]
    2x^3 + 6x^2 + 8x + 24 &= 2x^3 + (e+6)x^2 + (8+3e)x +24
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Equating the coefficients of $x^2$ and $x$ on the LHS and RHS, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    6 &= e + 6 \\[6pt]
    8 &= 8 + 3e
    \end{align*}
    $$

    We must have $e=0$. Therefore

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    P(x) &= (x+3)(2x^2 + 8) \\[8pt]
    &\hspace{-2.1em}\tcbhighmath{P(x) = 2(x+3)(x^2 + 4)}
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - We have from part (b)(i) that $x_1=-3$. To find the other two roots, we solve $x^2+4=0$:

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    x^2+4&=0 \\[6pt]
    x^2 &= -4 \\[6pt]
    x &= \pm \sqrt{-4} \\[6pt]
    x &= \pm 2\mathrm{i}
    \end{align*}
    $$

    $\boxed{\text{The roots of } P(x) \text{ are } x_1=-3,\, x_2=-2\mathrm{i}, \text{ and } x_3=2\mathrm{i}.}$

list.title: Question 18
list.content: This question asks you to investigate some properties of cubic functions and their tangents. Consider the cubic function $q(x)=x^3-6x^2-x+30$. - - Show that $x=5$ is a root of $q(x)=0$. - Hence, express $q(x)$ as a product of linear factors. - Find the equation of the tangent to $y=q(x)$ at $x=4$. - Sketch $y=q(x)$ and the tangent at $x=4$ on the same set of axes. [9] Consider the cubic function $f(x)=ax^3+bx^2+cx+d, \, a\neq 0,$ and the line $L(x)=mx+1$, with the point $(x_\ast, f(x_\ast))$ being a point of inflection on $f(x)$. Let $x_1,x_2,x_3$ be the roots of the equation $f(x)-L(x)=0.$ - - Show that the sum of the roots is a constant which is independent of the choice of line $L$. - Show that $y=f(x)$ has an inflection point at $x_\ast=\dfrac{x_1+x_2+x_3}{3}.$ [5] Suppose $y=L(x)$ is a tangent to $y=f(x)$ at the point $x=x_1$. - - Show that $f'(x)-L'(x)=3a(x-x_1)(x-\beta)$ for some $\beta$. - Hence show that $f(x)-L(x)=\dfrac{a}{2}(x-x_1)^2(2x+x_1-3\beta)$. - Assuming it exists, find the $x$-coordinate of the other point of intersection between the cubic and the line, in terms of $x_1$ and $x_\ast$. - Sketch the functions $f(x)$ and $L(x)$ on the same axes identifying the $x$-coordinate of the points of intersection and inflection. - In the case that $L(x)=0$, interpret the result in (c)(iii) in terms of the graph of the cubic function and its $x$-intercepts. [13]

list.title: Question 19
list.content: - Show that $\cos{3\theta}=4\cos^3{\theta}-3\cos{\theta}$. [4] Consider the following function $$ \begin{align*} f(x)&=4x^3-3x-\cos{3k} \end{align*} $$ Where $k$ is an angle in degrees such that $0 \leq k \leq 360^\circ$. - Hence, verify that $\cos{k}$ is one of the roots of $f(x)$.[2] Let the remaining two roots of $f(x)$ be $\alpha$ and $\beta$. - - Find $\alpha\beta$ in terms of $\cos{k}$. - Show that $\beta=-\alpha-\cos k$.[3] - Using your answers from part (c) show that $\alpha^2+\alpha \cos k +\cos^2 k -\tfrac{3}{4}=0$. [2] - Hence show that $\alpha = \frac{-\cos k + \sqrt{3}\sin k}{2}$ and $\beta = \frac{-\cos k - \sqrt{3}\sin k}{2}$. [4] It is known that for $0 \leq k \leq 360^\circ$ $f(x)$ has either $3$ distinct roots or a single distinct root and a repeated root. - Hence, find all of the values of $k$ for which $f(x)$ intersects the $x-$axis exactly $2$ times. [7]

list.title: Question 20
list.content: The cubic polynomial equation $x^3 + bx^2 + cx + d = 0$ has three roots $x_1, x_2$ and $x_3$. By expanding the product $(x-x_1)(x-x_2)(x-x_3)$, show that - - $b = -(x_1+x_2+x_3)$; - $c = x_1x_2 + x_1x_3 + x_2x_3$; - $d = -x_1x_2x_3$. [3] It is given that $b = -9$ and $c = 45$ for parts (b) and (c) below. - - In the case that the three roots $x_1, x_2$ and $x_3$ form an arithmetic sequence, show that one of the roots is $3$. - Hence determine the value of $d$. [5] - In another case the three roots form a geometric sequence. Determine the value of $d$. [6]
list.markScheme:
- Given the three roots $x_1$, $x_2$ and $x_3$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x^3 + bx^2 + cx + d &= (x-x_1)(x-x_2)(x-x_3) \\[6pt]
  &= (x^2 -(x_1+x_2)x + x_1x_2)(x-x_3) \\[8pt]
  &= x^3 - (x_1+x_2+x_3)x^2 + (x_1x_2+x_1x_3+x_2x_3)x - x_1x_2x_3\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, comparing the coefficients, we get
  
  - $\answer{b = -(x_1+x_2+x_3)}$
  - $\answer{c = x_1x_2 + x_1x_3 + x_2x_3}$
  - $\answer{d = -x_1x_2x_3}$

- 
  - Letting $\alpha = x_1 + \delta$, where $\delta$ is the common
difference of the arithmetic sequence $x_1$, $x_2$, $x_3$, we
have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.8em} x_1  &=  \alpha - \delta \\[6pt]
    x_2  &=  \alpha \\[6pt]
    x_3  &=  \alpha + \delta\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence, using part (a)
(i), we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    x_1 + x_2 + x_3 &= -b \\[6pt]
    (\alpha - \delta) + \alpha + (\alpha + \delta) &= -(-9) \hspace{6em} \\[6pt]
    3\alpha &= 9 \\[6pt]
    \alpha &= 3 \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \answer{x_2 = 3}
    $$

  - Using part (a) (ii), we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    x_1x_2 + x_1x_3 + x_2x_3 &= c \\[6pt]
    (3 - \delta)(3) + (3 - \delta)(3 + \delta) + (3)(3 + \delta) &= 45 \\[6pt]
    27 - \delta^2 &= 45 \\[6pt]
    -\delta^2 &= 18 \\[5pt]
    \delta &= \sqrt{18}\hspace{0.05em}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\hspace{2em}\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence, using part (a) (iii), we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{4em} d &= -x_1x_2x_3 \\[5pt]
    &= -(3-\sqrt{18}\hspace{0.05em}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})(3)(3+\sqrt{18}\hspace{0.05em}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}) \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= -81}\end{aligned}
    $$


- Letting $\alpha = x_1$ and $r$ denote the common ratio of the
geometric sequence $x_1, x_2, x_3$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.2em} x_1  &=  \alpha \\[6pt]
  x_2  &=  \alpha r \\[6pt]
  x_3  &=  \alpha r^2\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{7.25em} x_1 + x_2 + x_3 &= -b \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (a) (i)}] \\[6pt]
  \alpha + \alpha r + \alpha r^2 &= -(-9) \\[6pt]
  \alpha (1+r+r^2) &= 9 \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x_1x_2 + x_1x_3 + x_2x_3 &= c \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (a) (ii)}] \\[6pt]
  \alpha (\alpha r) + \alpha (\alpha r^2) + (\alpha r)(\alpha r^2) &= 45 \\[6pt]
  \alpha^2r(1+r+r^2) &= 45 \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Taking the ratio
of the expressions $(1)$ and $(2)$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{\alpha^2r(\cancel{1+r+r^2})}{\alpha(\cancel{1+r+r^2})} &= \dfrac{45}{9} \hspace{4em} \\[5pt]
  \dfrac{\alpha^2r}{\alpha} &= \dfrac{45}{9} \\[15pt]
  \alpha r &= 5 \qref{(3)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the expression $(3)$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6.5em} d &= -x_1x_2x_3 \hspace{3em} [\text{by (a) (iii)}] \\[5pt]
  &= -\alpha (\alpha r)(\alpha r^2) \\[5pt]
  &= -(\alpha r)^3 \\[5pt]
  &= -5^3 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= -125}\end{aligned}
  $$
